tests package

Submodules

tests.conftest module

tests.conftest.app()[source]

The app method is a fixture that initializes and configures a Flask application for testing purposes.

The method creates a Flask app instance, sets the necessary app context, and updates the app configuration for testing. It initializes the SQLAlchemy database by dropping and creating * all tables and inserts some initial data into the database.

Additionally, it sets up an API instance and maps the repair endpoints using the RepairEndPointsMapper class. Lastly, it registers the repairs blueprint with the app.

Returns:

The initialized Flask app instance.

tests.conftest.client(app) → FlaskClient[source]
Parameters:

app – Flask application instance.

Returns:

FlaskClient instance for testing the application.

tests.conftest.sqlalchemy_database_uri()[source]

tests.test_create_app module

tests.test_create_app.test_create_app(sqlalchemy_database_uri: object) → object[source]
Parameters:

sqlalchemy_database_uri – The SQLAlchemy database URI to use for creating the test Flask application.

Returns:

The test Flask application object.

This method is used to test the create_app function by asserting various conditions on the test Flask application object. It creates a test Flask application using the main function * and performs the following assertions: 1. Asserts that the test Flask application object is not None. 2. Asserts that the test Flask application object is an instance of the Flask class. 3. Asserts that the SQLAlchemy database URI configuration property of the test Flask application matches the provided sqlalchemy_database_uri parameter. 4. Asserts that the SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS configuration property of the test Flask application is set to False.

Note: This method does not return anything, as the purpose is to perform the assertions and verify the behavior of the create_app function.

tests.test_drivers_routes module

class tests.test_drivers_routes.TestCRUDDriversRoutes[source]

Bases: object

Test the creation of a driver with valid data.

Parameters:

  • client – The client object to make HTTP requests.

  • driver_data – The data of the driver to be created.

  • desired_response_data – The expected response data upon successful creation of the driver.

Returns:

None

test_create_driver_with_valid_data(client, driver_data, desired_response_data) → None[source]
Parameters:

  • client (object) – The client object used for making the HTTP request.

  • driver_data (dict) – The data representing the driver to be created.

  • desired_response_data (dict) – The expected response data after creating the driver.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

This method tests the creation of a driver with valid data by making an HTTP POST request to the ‘/driver’ endpoint using the provided client object and driver data. It then asserts * that the response status code is equal to 201 (indicating successful creation) and that the response data matches the desired_response_data.

Example usage:

client = create_client() driver_data = {‘name’: ‘John Doe’, ‘license_number’: ‘ABC123’} desired_response_data = {‘id’: 1, ‘name’: ‘John Doe’, ‘license_number’: ‘ABC123’} test_create_driver_with_valid_data(client, driver_data, desired_response_data)

Raises:

AssertionError: If the response status code is not equal to 201 or the response data does not match the desired_response_data.

test_delete_driver_by_id(client, driver_data) → None[source]

None

Example:

client = create_test_client()
driver_data = {
    "id": 1,
    "name": "John Doe",
    "license": "ABC123"
}
test_delete_driver_by_id(client, driver_data)
test_delete_driver_by_id_when_doesnt_exists(client) → None[source]
Parameters:

client – The client object used to make the HTTP request.

Returns:

None

Deletes a driver with the given ID when it doesn’t exist.

This method sends a DELETE request to the ‘/driver/1’ endpoint of the client object to delete a driver with ID ‘1’. It then asserts that the response status code is 404 (Not Found) and * the response JSON contains a message indicating that the driver was not found.

test_get_one_by_id_that_not_exist(client) → None[source]

test_update_driver_by_id(client, driver_data, desired_response_data) → None[source]
Parameters:

  • client – the client object used to send requests to the API

  • driver_data – the data of the driver to be updated

  • desired_response_data – the expected data of the response

Returns:

None

Test method to verify the functionality of updating a driver by ID.

  1. Sends a POST request to create a new driver using client object and driver_data.

  2. Sends a PATCH request to update the driver with ID=1 using client object and the provided email in the request payload.

  3. Asserts that the response status code is 200, indicating a successful update.

  4. Asserts that the response JSON data matches the desired_response_data merged with the provided email in the request payload.
